The "Hidden Rate Elimination Act of 2001" is introduced with a short title. Any amendments or repeals in the Act refer to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act ensures that no changes in tax rates will be considered under section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code. Additionally, there is a reduction in marginal income tax rates for individuals. The "Hidden Rate Elimination Act of 2001" introduces a reduction in marginal income tax rates for married individuals filing joint returns and surviving spouses for the year 2002. For taxable income not over $12,000, the tax is 14% of taxable income. For income over $12,000 but not over $45,200, the tax is $1,680 plus 15% of the excess over $12,000. For income over $45,200 but not over $109,250, the tax is $6,660 plus 27% of the excess over $45,200. For income over $109,250 but not over $166,450, the tax is $23,953.50 plus 30% of the excess over $109,250. For taxable income over $166,450 but not over $297,300, the tax is $41,113.50 plus 35% of the excess. For income over $297,300, the tax is $86,911 plus 38% of the excess. Heads of Households are subject to a separate tax rate. For heads of households, the tax rate is $86,911 plus 38% of income over $297,300. For taxable income over $297,300 for heads of households, the tax rate is $86,911 plus 38% of the excess amount. For unmarried individuals, the tax rates are as follows:
- Over $93,600 but not over $151,600: $20,822 plus 30% of the excess
- Over $151,600 but not over $297,300: $38,222 plus 35% of the excess
- Over $297,300: $89,217 plus 38% of the excess. For unmarried individuals, the tax rates are as follows: $89,217 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300. If taxable income is not over $6,000, the tax is 14% of taxable income. If it is over $6,000 but not over $27,050, the tax is $840 plus 15% of the excess over $6,000. If it is over $27,050 but not over $65,550, the tax is $3,997.50 plus 27% of the excess over $27,050. If it is over $65,550 but not over $136,750, the tax is $14,362.50 plus 30% of the excess over $65,550. For taxable income over $136,750 but not over $297,300, the tax is $35,752.50 plus 35% of the excess over $136,750. For taxable income over $297,300, the tax is $91,945 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300 for married individuals filing separate returns. For married individuals filing separate returns, a tax of $91,945 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300 is imposed on taxable income. If taxable income is not over $6,000, the tax is 14% of taxable income. If it is over $6,000 but not over $22,600, the tax is $840 plus 15% of the excess over $6,000. If it is over $22,600 but not over $54,625, the tax is $3,330 plus 27% of the excess over $22,600. If it is over $54,625 but not over $83,225, the tax is $11,976.75 plus 30% of the excess over $54,625. If it is over $83,225 but not over $148,650, the tax is imposed based on a different formula. The tax rates for taxable income over $54,625 are $11,976.75 plus 30% of the excess over $54,625, for income over $83,225 but not over $148,650 the rate is $20,556.75 plus 35% of the excess, and for income over $148,650 the rate is $43,455.50 plus 38% of the excess. Phasein of Rate Reductions is also mentioned in the section. The tax rates for income over $148,650 are $43,455.50 plus 38% of the excess. Phasein of Rate Reductions is mentioned in the section. Tax rates determined under subsections (a), (b), (c), or (d) in a calendar year after 2002 will be based on the rates imposed in taxable years beginning in 2002, with reductions in subsequent years. The 14 percent rate will decrease by 1 percentage point annually from 2003 to 2006, while the 27 and 35 percent rates will decrease by 1 percentage point in 2004 and an additional 1 percentage point in 2006. In taxable years after 2002, tax rates will decrease annually. The 14 percent rate will decrease by 1 percentage point each year from 2003 to 2006. The 27 and 35 percent rates will decrease by 1 percentage point in 2004 and an additional 1 percentage point in 2006. Additionally, the 30 and 38 percent rates will decrease by 1 percentage point each year from 2003 to 2006, and by an additional 2 percentage points in 2006. The Secretary will adjust the tables to reflect these reductions. In 2002, tax rates will decrease annually. Additionally, for calendar years 2002 through 2006, the Secretary shall make no adjustment to the dollar amounts at which the first rate bracket begins or at which the second rate. The Secretary will not adjust dollar amounts for tax rate brackets for taxable years after 2001 and before 2007. For later years, adjustments will be made based on cost-of-living adjustments. In taxable years after 2006, cost-of-living adjustments will be made by substituting '2005' for '2000' in certain provisions. Amendments are made to provisions by replacing '1992' with '2000' in various sections. The effective dates for these changes are specified for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF PHASEOUTS OF DEDUCTION FOR PERSONAL EXEMPTIONS AND OF ITEMIZED DEDUCTIONS. Repeal of Phaseout of Personal Exemptions, amending subsection (d) of section 151 by striking paragraph (3) and making technical amendments to sections 1(f) and 151(d). The text chunk discusses amending section 151(d) by adjusting the dollar amount for inflation in taxable years after 1989. This involves multiplying the dollar amount by the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. The text chunk repeals section 68 and makes technical amendments to section 1(f)(6)(A) by removing references to section 68(b)(2).
